content.description: Stand start the arête on the backside of the boulder. It is really technical and a cool, new addition.
content.location: This ascends the arête on the backside of the boulder. Park at the cemetery (Mt. Jacob Boulders), and walk straight in for 4-5 minutes to find this whitish egg perched on the ridge.

content.description: Begin with a low sit start on the gently overhanging face. Start with your left hand on a decent crimpy sidepull and your right hand on anything of use. Power up to a series of crimps, then bust a big move right to the feature, move up, and top out.
content.location: From the road, follow the trail. As it turns to the left, there will be a cube-shaped boulder on the right side of the trail. Go to the back of that boulder, and then walk 4-5 minutes straight into the woods to find this boulder near the shore of the swamp.

content.description: Begin with a low sit start on the left side of the arête. Move up a few feet and transition onto the right side of the arête, and make a tall topout.
content.location: Follow the trail into Mount Jacob. Bear right at the intersection, and follow that trail for about 5 minutes. At the bottom of the short hill, creak right uphill about 150 feet to find this tall wall.

content.description: Sit start the arête and move up to the slopey lip, and traverse left to top out at the peak.
content.location: This ascends the far right arête on the wall.

content.description: Sit start the right face/arete using the rock pedestal for feet. It is fingery, slopey, and balancy.
content.location: Follow the directions for the problem Special Delivery.

content.description: Sit start the right arête that faces the trail with left hand on a higher, small crimp and right hand on a lower decent knob. Move left and up to top out.
content.location: Walk in at the cemetery, and go straight into the woods for 3-4 minutes. This egg is perched on a ridge.

content.description: Stand start the face that faces away from the cemetery.
content.location: Take the trail from the street, and after a minute just as it curves to the left, you will see this cube shaped boulder on the right of the trail.

content.description: Stand start matched on a V-shaped sloper shelf, and move up on good holds and crap feet.
content.location: As you approach the Cemetery Boulders, look to the right on the first boulder.

content.description: Sit start and move up the deceptive, short arete. Definitely harder if you are on the shorter side.
content.location: Park at the pullout for the Mt. Jacob Boulders. Walk in and bear to the left on the trail. As the trail begins to turn right and head uphill, this short arete will be at the top on your right.

content.description: Sit start matched on a good, round hold low on the arête. Bump your left hand to a good hold, and then traverse left up the rising lip on marginal holds. This rig is short and burly. The grade is for the low start described.
content.location: This boulder is located about 120 feet from the street in a small patch of woods between the Cemetery parking pullout and the three car dirt pullout used for the Mount Jacob Boulders.

content.description: Sit start the far left, overhanging arete.
content.location: From the street, follow the trail as it curves left, and then as it turns right and uphill, this block is on your left.

content.description: Stand start the face on the side facing away from the cemetery.
content.location: Walk-in to the cemetery. and then go straight into the woods for 3-4 minutes to find this egg perched on a ridge.

content.description: Begin with a low sit start on marginal crimps. Move straight up to a sketch topout.
content.location: This ascends the steep, undercut, rounded arête on the painted boulder near the water.

content.description: This is a collection of 10-15 blocks within a minute of the cemetery.
